data.title: Darin Givens on LinkedIn: To Expand Transit on the Cheap, Cities Explore Infill Stations
data.meta_description: Thanks to Bloomberg for interviewing me for this piece. It's kinda funny that I got the last word in & that it's a word of caution.

As New York City gears up for the implementation of its Central Business District Tolling Program in 2024, opinions are divided among New Yorkers. Some see it as a necessary step towards reducing traffic congestion and funding transit improvements, while others are concerned about the cost implications. The program, also known as congestion pricing, is set to charge drivers a toll for entering Manhattan south of and including 60th Street. With toll rates varying by vehicle type and time of day, the initiative aims to decrease traffic, improve air quality, and enhance public transportation. In Canada, only Vancouver City is considering a mobility pricing (similar to congestion pricing) for vehicles entering downtown. #NYC #CongestionPricing #TransitImprovement #UrbanPlanning #vancouver #mobilitypricing

A century-long dream comes to fruition! The Biden administration, with Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg's support, is kick-starting the long-dormant Phase Two of the Second Avenue subway project in Manhattan. This extension will bring Q trains up to East Harlem, benefiting over 100,000 daily riders. The federal government is providing an historic $3.4 billion for this phase, which includes stations at 106th Street, 116th Street, and a new terminal at 125th Street with connections to the 4, 5, 6 trains and Metro North. ‚ÄúIt's going towards a public transit project serving neighborhoods that have been neglected for years ensuring East Harlem has greater access to jobs, health care and other essential services‚Äù said Sen. Chuck Schumer. ‚ÄúThis is uptown Grand Central," Congressman Adriano Espaillat said. "Finally, it's a day of reckoning. Finally, people recognize that this is a community that matters," Gov. Residents & businesses invited to South Main Street Corridor Study Open House March 13! The Town of Wake Forest is in the process of conducting a study to evaluate the access and mobility along the South Main Street/US 1A corridor. Upon completion, the initiative will recommend ways to improve the safety, comfort, access, and multimodal mobility for everyone that uses the corridor, including drivers, cyclists, and pedestrians. Public input is a major component of the South Main Street Corridor Study. Area residents are invited to attend an open house Wednesday, March 13, from 6-8 p.m. at the front entrance of The Factory, 1839 S. Main St. During the open house, attendees will be presented with two high-level concepts for improving traffic and safety along the South Main Street/US 1A corridor. These concepts are designed to mitigate several of the traffic and safety concerns expressed by the public and transform the corridor into an attractive, green gateway into the heart of Wake Forest. The March 13 session will have an informal, open house-style format, so attendees may drop in anytime from 6-8 p.m. to view displays, ask questions, and share comments. South Main Street/US 1A is an NCDOT-owned and maintained roadway extending from Capital Boulevard/US1 to South Ave, with the study focusing on the roadway between Capital Boulevard/US1 to Dr. Calvin Jones Highway/NC 98 Bypass.‚Äù As one of the major vehicular connections in Town, the corridor is heavily travelled. Uncontrolled access and limited multimodal infrastructure have created significant safety concerns throughout the corridor. The 2019 Comprehensive Transportation Plan (CTP) indicated high levels of crashes on the corridor. Scheduled for completion later this year, the South Main Street Corridor Study has two main goals: 1) Evaluate existing roadway capacity and volume, safety, future traffic growth, impacts to cultural and historic resources, and multi-modal access; and 2) Provide a high-level concept design of the entire corridor with recommended solutions for access management, intersections, and multi-modal connectivity along the corridor. For more information and updates about the South Main Street Corridor Study, visit wakeforestnc.gov and search ‚ÄúSouth Main Street Study‚Äù or contact Long Range Planning Manager Brad West at 919-435-9542 or bwest@wakeforestnc.gov. #TownofWakeForest #WakeForestNC #TOWFplanning

With all of the talk about the Rozelle Interchange, I think it's important to remember what the community, particularly in the Inner West, were promised at the project's inception. The entire Westconnex was based in part on the premise of placing traffic essentially underground to free up Victoria Road and Parramatta Road as 'boulevards' - with better urban amenity and more public transport. I keep seeing "7 lanes to 4 now 10 lanes to 4" causing traffic issues cited in media. Is this not our opportunity to go back to 7, but this time, by returning lanes back to people, and making Victoria Road and Parramatta Road streets again? We seem to be at risk of forgetting that this was to be an integrated solution to improving Sydney's urban fabric. #roads #traffic #trafficmanagement #nswgovernment #cityplanning #urbanplanning #sydney https://lnkd.in/grzWDF2k
